ref: 6196 dardara ʻ split, broken ʼ lex. &rcirclemacr Pa. daddara -- m. ʻ noise of grinding ʼ; K. dŏduru ʻ decayed, rotten ʼ, dadürü f. ʻ hollow tree, hollow in a tree ʼ; S. ḍ̠aḍ̠aru ʻ coarsely ground ʼ, m. ʻ piece of anything coarsely ground or pounded ʼ; L. (Ju.) ḍ̠aḍ̠rā ʻ coarsely ground ʼ, P. dardarā (< *draddarā? see also daráyati); Or. dadarā ʻ cracked, slightly broken, worn ʼ; H. dadrī f. ʻ unripe corn cut from time to time and brought home for eating without being taken to the threshing floor ʼ; G. dodrũ ʻ shattered ʼ (o < ā in NG. LSI ix Pt. ii 329), dã̄drũ n. ʻ roughness of skin ʼ; Si. dädura ʻ a rent, a split, sound as of distant thunder ʼ, diya -- dädura ʻ showerbath ʼ (semant. cf. N. darkanu s.v. daráyati); -- ʻ *hole, notch ʼ (cf. K. dadürü ab.) in Pk. daddara -- m. ʻ ladder, staircase ʼ; Ku. dādar ʻ slats on roof to which slates or tiles are fastened ʼ; M. dādar n. ʻ ladderlike and movable staircase, shutter over a staircase, bridge ʼ, dādrī f. ʻ bridge ʼ, dādrā m. ʻ shutter over staircase, hole in roof for smoke -- vent, cloth tied over a vessel ʼ.
